revision.text:
'''The American Empire Project''' is a book series that deals with what they theorized were [[Imperialism|imperialist]] and [[Exceptionalism|exceptionalist]] tendencies in recent [[foreign policy of the United States|US foreign policy]]. The series is published by [[Metropolitan Books]] and includes contributions by notable authors such as [[Noam Chomsky]], [[Howard Zinn]], [[Chalmers Johnson]] and [[Andrew Bacevich]]. The project's goal is to provide a critical look at what they called the imperial ambitions of the United States and to explore viable alternatives for foreign policy.
The American Empire Project was founded by [[Tom Engelhardt]] and [[Steven Fraser]] and started publication in 2004. The series comprises 32 books as at August 2017<ref>[http://americanempireproject.com/category/books/ List of books at americanempireproject.com] Accessed August 3, 2017</ref> and is continuously expanded.
==The American Empire Project Book List== Accessed March 2010: <ref>[http://www.americanempireproject.com/booklist.asp The American Empire Project Book List], American Empire Project, accessed March 31, 2010.</ref>
*A People's History of American Empire; by [[Howard Zinn]], [[Paul Buhle]], [[Mike Konopacki]] *A Question of Torture: CIA Interrogation, from the Cold War to the War on Terror; by [[Alfred W. McCoy|Alfred McCoy]] *Ain’t My America: The Long, Noble History of Antiwar Conservatism and Middle-American Anti-Imperialism; by [[Bill Kauffman]] *Blood and Oil: The Dangers and Consequences of America's Growing Petroleum Dependency; by [[Michael T. Klare]] *Blowback: The Costs and Consequences of American Empire, Revised edition; by [[Chalmers Johnson]] *Crusade: Chronicles of an Unjust War; by [[James Carroll (author)|James Carroll]] *Devil's Game: How the United States Helped Unleash Fundamentalist Islam; by [[Robert Dreyfuss]] *Dilemmas of Domination: The Unmaking of the American Empire; by [[Walden Bello]] *Empire's Workshop: Latin America, the United States, and the Rise of the New Imperialism; by [[Greg Grandin]] *Failed States: The Abuse of Power and the Assault on Democracy; by [[Noam Chomsky]] *Hegemony or Survival: America's Quest for Global Dominance; by Noam Chomsky *How to Succeed at Globalization: A Primer for Roadside Vendors; by [[El Fisgón]] *Imperial Ambitions: Conversations on the Post 9/11 World; by Noam Chomsky *In the Name of Democracy: American War Crimes in Iraq and Beyond; by [[Jeremy Brecher]], [[Jill Cutler]], and [[Brendan Smith]]{{dn|date=October 2018}} *Iraq: The Logic of Withdrawal; by [[Anthony Arnove]] *Nemesis: The Last Days of the American Republic; by Chalmers Johnson *The Seventh Decade: The New Shape of Nuclear Danger; by [[Jonathan Schell]] *The Sorrows of Empire: Militarism, Secrecy, and the End of the Republic; by Chalmers Johnson *The Complex: How the Military Invades Our Everyday Lives; by [[Nick Turse]] *The Limits of Power: The End of American Exceptionalism; by [[Andrew Bacevich]] *War Powers: How the Imperial Presidency Hijacked the Constitution; by [[Peter Irons]] *What We Say Goes: Conversations on U.S. Power in a Changing World: Interviews with David Barsamian; by Noam Chomsky and [[David Barsamian]]
==See also== * [[American century]] * [[American exceptionalism]] * [[American imperialism]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.americanempireproject.com American Empire Project homepage]
[[Category:Foreign relations of the United States]] [[Category:Metropolitan Books books]] [[Category:Series of books]]

page.title: Armendariz v. Foundation Health Psychcare Services, Inc.
At the Moulin Rouge, The Dance
Austin Nichols & Co Inc v Stichting Lodestar

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox Court Case | name = Austin Nichols & Co v Stichting Lodestar | court = [[Supreme Court of New Zealand]] | date_filed = | image = Coat of arms of New Zealand.svg | date decided = 11 December 2007 | full name = Austin Nichols & Co v Stichting Lodestar | citations = [2007] NZSC 103 | judges = [[Sian Elias|Elias]] CJ, [[Peter Blanchard|Blanchard]], [[Andrew Tipping|Tipping]], [[John McGrath (judge)|McGrath]] and [[Noel Anderson|Anderson]] JJ | prior actions = | subsequent actions = | opinions = | transcripts = http://www.nzlii.org/cgi-bin/sinodisp/nz/cases/NZSC/2007/103.html | Keywords = }}
'''''Austin Nichols & Co Inc v Stichting Lodestar''''' [2007] NZSC 103 is a decision of the [[Supreme Court of New Zealand]] handed down on 11 December 2007. It is the leading authority on the role of an appellate court in general appeals.
==Composition of the Court== [[Sian Elias|Elias]] CJ, [[Peter Blanchard|Blanchard]], [[Andrew Tipping|Tipping]], [[John McGrath (judge)|McGrath]] and [[Noel Anderson|Anderson]] JJ. The judgment was unanimous and united. Elias J delivered the Court's reasons.
==Decision== This was originally a trade mark dispute, but the importance of the case lies in the impact on civil procedure. Austin Nichols marketed a brand of bourbon called [[Wild Turkey (bourbon)|Wild Turkey]], Stichting Lodestar wished to register a whiskey called Wild Geese.
==Notes== <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Austin Nichols and Co Inc v Stichting Lodestar}} [[Category:2007 in New Zealand law]] [[Category:Supreme Court of New Zealand cases]] [[Category:2007 in case law]]
<!--This was appended to the bottom of the article with no reference: "The High Court as the superior court of original jurisdiction deciding a matter under s27(6) Trade Marks Act 1953 reached a different conclusion to the Trade Marks Commissioner though the latter acted reasonably. The appeal courts ruled that the High Court had to come to its own view on the merits, with the weight accorded the decision of the Commissioner being at discretion: "If the High Court is of a different view from the Commissioner and is, therefore, of opinion that the Commissioner’s decision is wrong, it must act on its own view.""-->
{{NewZealand-case-law-stub}}

page.title: Comparison of Cantonese and Standard Chinese

revision.comment: AfD: Nominated for deletion; see [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/NominationName]]
revision.text:
{{Article for deletion/dated|page=Comparison of Cantonese and Standard Chinese|timestamp=20181129014917|year=2018|month=November|day=29|substed=yes}} {{Contains special characters | special = [[Modifier Tone Letters]] | fix = Help:Multilingual support | error = [[Specials (Unicode block)#Replacement character|question marks, boxes, or other symbols]] | characters = the tone marking characters | image = Replacement character.svg | link = Specials (Unicode block)#Replacement character | alt = | compact = }} [[Cantonese]] and [[Standard Chinese]], also known as Mandarin, are both [[varieties of Chinese|Chinese language varieties]] ([[Sinitic languages]]). Mandarin is part of the [[Mandarin Chinese]] (Northern Chinese) branch, and Cantonese being part of the [[Yue Chinese]] branch. ==Vocabulary== Standard Chinese and Cantonese are estimated to have 19% [[lexical similarity]]. Many [[cognates]] exist, but there are also [[false friends]]. Cantonese has possible [[Tai-Kadai]] substrata. In fact, Mai states that Cantonese and Mandarin have 62% lexical similarity, instead of 23.1% and 1.8% as described by Li.{{cite thesis|title=Cantonese : Language or Dialect? |last=Mau|first= Wing Yan, Annie|year=2005|institution=[[University of Hong Kong]]}} A 2008 study suggested there is around 24% lexical similarity and 50% phonological similarity.{{cite paper|title=Mutual intelligibility and similarity of Chinese dialects - Predicting judgments from objective measures|first1=Chaoju |last1=Tang |first2= Vincent J.|last2= van Heuven|institution=Chongqing Jiaotong University / University of Leiden/LUCL}} ==Phonology== He states that the two varieties are similar in their phonology for only 21.5% of commonly-used words; and similar in lexical meanings and usage for only 23.1% of vocabulary entry.{{cite book|last=Li|first= J.Z.|year=1994|title=Yu yan yan bian lun|location=Guangzhou}} Mai says there are actually 63.7% phonological similarity between Cantonese and Mandarin.Mai. (1993). Yueyu shi Hanyu De yizhi fangyan 粵語是漢語的一支方言-與李敬忠 先生商榷 (Cantonese is a branch of Chinese dialect). Yu wen jian she tong xun 語文建設通訊 (Language Construction Newsletter). 41: 65-72. Beijing: Zhongguo xue shu qi kan (guang pan ban) dian zi za zhi she. Cantonese has 19 initials and 53 finals. Mandarin has 19 initials. Mandarin retains [[retroflex consonants]] from Middle Chinese, whereas Cantonese has lost them, albeit only in the early 20th century. Cantonese has [[vowel length]] as a [[distinctive feature]]. ===Tones=== Cantonese has 6 [[phonemic tones]] and 3 [[checked tone]]s. Mandarin is described as having 4 phonemic tones and a [[neutral tone]]. The following chart describes the correspondence of tones compared to the [[four tones (Middle Chinese)|Four Tones]] of [[Middle Chinese]]. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |+ Distribution of the four tone classes in modern Chinese
Each tone class is numbered {{lang|zh|①}} to {{lang|zh|⑧}}, depending on its reflex of Late Middle Chinese, followed by its actual pronunciation, using a [[tone letter]] to illustrate its contour and then a [[tone letter#Tone letters as numerals|numerical equivalent]]. |- !rowspan=5|major group!!rowspan=5|subgroup!!rowspan=5|local variety!!colspan=14 style="background:#b3d7ff;"|Early Middle Chinese tone class!!rowspan=5|number of
tone classes
(number of
phonemic tones) |- |colspan=3 style="background:#d8eaff;"|{{lang|zh|꜀'''平'''}} '''Level''' {{lang|zh|꜀①꜁②}}||colspan=3 style="background:#d8eaff;"|{{lang|zh|꜂'''上'''}} '''Rising''' {{lang|zh|꜂③꜃④}}||colspan=4 style="background:#d8eaff;"|{{lang|zh|'''去'''꜄}} '''Departing''' {{lang|zh|⑤꜄⑥꜅}}||colspan=4 style="background:#d8eaff;"|{{lang|zh|'''入'''꜆}} '''Entering''' {{lang|zh|⑦꜆⑧꜇}} |- !colspan=14 style="background:#ffcdff;"|[[Syllable onset]] |- !rowspan=2 style="background:#ffe5ff;"|[[voiceless]]!!colspan=2 style="background:#ffe5ff;"|[[voice (phonetics)|voiced]]!!rowspan=2 style="background:#ffe5ff;"|voiceless!!colspan=2 style="background:#ffe5ff;"|voiced!!colspan=2 style="background:#ffe5ff;"|voiceless!!colspan=2 style="background:#ffe5ff;"|voiced!! colspan=2 style="background:#ffe5ff;"|voiceless!!colspan=2 style="background:#ffe5ff;"|voiced |- !style="background:#ffe5ff;"|[[sonorant|son]]!!style="background:#ffe5ff;"|[[obstruent|obs]]!!style="background:#ffe5ff;"|son!!style="background:#ffe5ff;"|obs!! style="background:#ffe5ff;"|[[tenuis stop|tenuis]]!! style="background:#ffe5ff;"|[[aspirated consonant|asp]]!!style="background:#ffe5ff;"|son!!style="background:#ffe5ff;"|obs!!(short)!!(long)!!style="background:#ffe5ff;"|son!!style="background:#ffe5ff;"|obs |- |rowspan=1|[[Mandarin Chinese|Mandarin]]||colspan=2|[[Beijing dialect|Beijing]]||① {{IPA|˥}} 55||colspan=2|②ʰ {{IPA|˧˥}} 35||colspan=2|③ {{IPA|˨˩˦}} 214||colspan=5|Mandarin 4th tone⑤{{IPA|˥˩}} 51||colspan=2|(any)§||⑤||②||4 |- |rowspan=3|[[Yue Chinese|Yue]]||[[Yuehai dialects|Yuehai]]||[[Cantonese]]||①a {{IPA|˥}} 55 ~ {{nowrap|①b {{IPA|˥˧}} 53}}||colspan=2|②ʰ {{IPA|˨˩}} 21~11||③ {{IPA|˧˥}} 35||colspan=2|④ʰ* {{IPA|˩˧}} 13||colspan=2|⑤ {{IPA|˧}} 33||colspan=2|⑥ {{IPA|˨}} 22|| ⑦a̚ {{IPA|˥}} 5|| ⑦b̚ {{IPA|˧}} 3||colspan=2|⑧̚ {{IPA|˨}} 2||9~10 (6~7) |- |[[Siyi dialect|Siyi]]||[[Taishanese]]||① {{IPA|˧}} 33||colspan=2|②ʰ? {{IPA|˩}} 11||③ {{IPA|˥}} 55||colspan=2|④ʰ? {{IPA|˨˩}} 21||colspan=2|① ||colspan=2|⑥ {{IPA|˧˨}} 32|| ⑦a̚ {{IPA|˥}} 5|| ⑦b̚ {{IPA|˧}} 3||colspan=2|⑧̚ {{IPA|˨˩}} 21||8 (5) |- |[[Gou-Lou Yue|Gou-Lou]]||[[Bobai]]||① {{IPA|˦}} 44||colspan=2|②ʰ? {{IPA|˨˧}} 23||③ {{IPA|˧}} 33||colspan=2|④ʰ? {{IPA|˦˥}} 45||colspan=2|⑤ {{IPA|˧˨}} 32||colspan=2|⑥ {{IPA|˨˩}} 21|| ⑦a̚ {{IPA|˥˦}} 54|| ⑦b̚ {{IPA|˩}} 1|| ⑧a̚ {{IPA|˦}} 4
(long)|| ⑧b̚ {{IPA|˧˨}} 32
(short)||10 (6) |} ==Comparison to Middle Chinese== Cantonese is thought to be one of the closest extant varieties of Chinese to [[Middle Chinese]]. On the other hand, Mandarin retains a few features such as the [[retroflex consonant]], which was lost in most southern Chinese varieties. ==Grammar== Both are [[analytic language]]s. Cantonese has different grammatical particles. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Cantonese]] [[Category:Standard Chinese]] [[Category:Language comparison]]

page.title: Comparison of the imperial and US customary measurement systems

revision.text:
{{outline|Imperial and US customary measurement systems}} {{Unreferenced|date=October 2009}} [[Image:MetricImperialUSCustomaryUnits.jpg|200px|thumb|right|A baby bottle with measurements in metric, imperial and US customary]] [[Image:GasCan.jpg|200px|thumb|right|A one-US-gallon petrol (or gasoline) can be purchased near the US–Canada border showing equivalents in imperial gallons and litres]] Both the [[Imperial unit|imperial]] and [[United States customary units|United States customary]] [[systems of measurement]] derive from earlier [[English units|English systems]] used in the Middle Ages, that were the result of a combination of the local [[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] units inherited from German tribes and [[Ancient Roman weights and measures|Roman units]] brought by [[William the Conqueror]] after the [[Norman Conquest of England]] in 1066. Having this shared heritage, the two systems are quite similar, but there are differences. The US customary system is based on English systems of the 18th century, while the Imperial system was defined in 1824, after [[Declaration of Independence (United States)|American independence]]. ==Volume== Volume may be measured either in terms of units of cubic length or with specific volume units. The units of cubic length (the cubic inch, cubic foot, cubic mile, etc.) are the same in the imperial and US customary systems but with the specific units of volume (the [[bushel]], [[gallon]], [[fluid ounce]], etc.) they differ. The US customary system has one set of units for fluids and another set for dry goods. The imperial system has only one set defined independently of and subdivided differently from its US counterparts. By the end of the eighteenth century various systems of volume measurement were in use throughout the British Empire. Wine was measured with [[English wine cask units|units]] based on the [[wine gallon|Queen Anne's gallon]] of 231 cubic inches (3.785 L). Beer was measured with [[English brewery cask units|units]] based on an ale gallon of 282 cubic inches (4.621 L). Grain was measured with the [[Winchester measure]] with a gallon of approximately 268.8 cubic inches (one eighth of a Winchester bushel or 4.405 L). In 1824 these were replaced with a single system based on the imperial gallon.Wine gallons, however, continued to be used for tax purposes in the UK until the late 1990s. Originally defined as the volume of {{convert|10|lb|kg|1|lk=in}} of distilled water (under certain conditions),The water was to be weighed in air with brass weights with the barometer standing at {{convert|30|inHg|0|lk=in}} at a temperature of {{convert|62|°F|°C|0|lk=in}}. In 1963 these conditions were redefined such that the water was to have a density of {{val|0.998859|u=g/mL}} and to be weighed in air of density {{val|0.001217|u=g/mL}} against weights of density 8.136 g/mL. then redefined by the [[Weights and Measures Act 1985]] to be exactly {{val|4.54609|u=L}} (277.4 cu in), the imperial gallon is close in size to the old ale gallon. The Winchester measure was made obsolete in the British Empire but remained in use in the US.Originally defined as the volume of a cylinder {{convert|18+1/2|in}} in diameter and {{convert|8|in}} deep, the Winchester bushel was redefined in the US as {{val|2150.42}} cubic inches. The Winchester bushel was replaced with an imperial bushel of 8 imperial gallons. The subdivisions of the bushel were maintained. As with US dry measures the imperial system divides the bushel into 4 pecks, 8 gallons, 32 quarts or 64 pints. Thus all of these imperial measures are about 3% larger than their US dry measure counterparts. Fluid measure is not as straightforward. The American colonists adopted a system based on the 231-cubic-inch wine gallon for all fluid purposes. This became the US fluid gallon. Both the imperial and US fluid gallon are divided into 4 quarts, 8 pints or 32 [[Gill (unit)|gills]].The gill is no longer in common use. However, whereas the US gill is divided into 4 US fluid ounces, the imperial gill is divided into 5 imperial fluid ounces. So whilst the imperial gallon, quart, pint and gill are about 20% larger than their US fluid measure counterparts, the fluid ounce is about 4% smaller.The now rarely used [[apothecaries' system]] of fluid measures further divides the fluid ounce into 8 [[dram (unit)|fluid drams]] or 480 [[minim (unit)|minims]]. Also in the imperial system there is a fluid scruple of 20 minims which is absent from the US customary system. Like the fluid ounce the dram and minim are about 4% smaller in the imperial system. Note that one [[avoirdupois|avoirdupois ounce]] of water has an approximate volume of one imperial fluid ounce at 62 °F (16.67 °C).160 imperial fluid ounces is equivalent to one imperial gallon, which is the approximate volume of 10 pounds or 160 avoirdupois ounces of water at 62 °F. This convenient fluid-ounce-to-avoirdupois-ounce relation does not exist in the US system. One noticeable comparison between the imperial system and the US system is between some Canadian and American beer bottles. Many Canadian brewers package beer in a 12-imperial-fluid-ounce bottles, which are 341 mL each. American brewers package their beer in 12-US-fluid-ounce bottles, which are 355 mL each. This results in the Canadian bottles being labelled as 11.5 fl oz in US units when imported into the United States. Because Canadian beer bottles predate the adoption of the Metric System in that country, they are still sold and labelled in Canada as 341 mL. Canned beer in Canada is sold and labelled in 355 mL cans, and when exported to the US are labelled as 12 fl oz. {| class="wikitable" |+ Comparison of current imperial, US and metric volume measures |colspan=5 style="background:white"|Notes: * Approximate values are denoted with ≈ * Exact values are denoted with ≡ * Definitions are marked in '''bold''' |- ! Unit name !! Imperial measures !! US fluid measures !! US dry measures !! Metric measures |------------ |- !colspan=5 style="background:white"|

≈ {{val|0.26417205236|u=USgal}} | ≈ {{val|0.90808298427|u=USdryqt}}
≈ {{val|0.22702074607|u=USdrygal}} | ≡ '''{{val|1000|u=mL}}'''
≡ '''{{val|1|u=L}}''' |} ==Length== The international [[yard]] is defined as exactly 0.9144 [[metre]]s. This definition was agreed by the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand through the [[international yard and pound]] agreement of 1959. The US survey [[foot (unit)|foot]] and survey mile have been maintained as separate units for surveying purposes to avoid the accumulation of error that would follow replacing them with the international versions, particularly with [[State Plane Coordinate System]]s. (The choice of unit for [[surveying]] purposes is based on the unit used when the [[Earth ellipsoid|overall framework]] or [[geodetic datum]] for the region was established, so that - for example - much of the former British empire still uses the Clarke foot for surveying.) The US survey foot is defined so that 1 metre is exactly 39.37 [[inch]]es, making the international foot of 0.3048 metres exactly two parts per million shorter. This is a difference of just over 3.2 mm or a little over one eighth of an inch per mile. The main units of length (inch, foot, yard and international [[mile]]) were the same in the US, though the US rarely uses some of the intermediate units, such as the [[chain (unit)|(surveyor's) chain]] (22 yards) and the [[furlong]] (220 yards). At one time the definition of the [[nautical mile]] was based on the sphere whose surface is the same as the Clarke Ellipsoid. In the US, the full value of 1853.256 metres was used, but in the Commonwealth, this was rounded to 6080 feet (1853.184 m). These have been replaced by the international version, which rounds the sixtieth part of the 45° to the nearest metre, as 1852 metres. ==Weight and mass== [[File:English mass units graph.svg|250px|thumbnail|right|Relation of English mass weights to one another]] Traditionally, both Britain and the US used three different weight systems: [[troy weight]] for precious metals, [[avoirdupois]] weight for most other purposes and [[apothecaries' weight]] for medicines. However, apothecaries' weight has now been superseded by the metric system. One important difference is the widespread use in Britain of the [[stone (weight)|stone]] of 14 pounds ({{val|6.35029318|u=kg}}) for body weight. This unit is not used in the United States, although its influence was seen in the practice, until World War II, of selling [[flour]] by a barrel of 196 pounds (14 stone). Another difference arose when Britain abolished the ''[[troy pound]]'' ({{val|373.2417216|u=g}}) on January 6, 1879, leaving only the ''[[troy ounce]]'' ({{val|31.1034768|u=g}}) and its [[decimal]] subdivisions, whereas the troy pound (of 12 troy ounces) and [[pennyweight]] are still legal in the United States, although no longer widely used. In all the systems, the fundamental unit is the [[pound (mass)|pound]] (lb), and all other units are defined as fractions or multiples of it. The tables of imperial troy mass and apothecaries' mass are the same as the corresponding United States tables, except for the British spelling "drachm" in the table of apothecaries' mass. The table of imperial avoirdupois mass is the same as the United States table up to 1 pound, but above that point the tables differ. The imperial system has a hundredweight, defined as eight stone or 112 lb ({{val|50.80234544|u=kg}}), whereas a US hundredweight is 100 lb ({{val|45.359237|u=kg}}). In both systems, 20 hundredweights make a [[ton]]. In the US, the terms ''[[long ton]]'' ({{val|2240|u=lb}}, {{val|1016.0469088|u=kg}}) and ''[[short ton]]'' ({{val|2000|u=lb}}; {{val|907.18474|u=kg}}) are used to distinguish them. The term ''metric ton'' is also used to denote a [[tonne]] ({{val|1000|u=kg}}, {{val|2204.622|u=lb}}), which is about 2% less than the long ton. == See also == * [[Conversion of units]] * [[History of measurement]] * [[Systems of measurement]] * [[Weights and measures]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=note}} {{systems of measurement}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Comparison Of The Imperial And US Customary Measurement Systems}} [[Category:Systems of units]] [[Category:Imperial units]] [[Category:Customary units of measurement in the United States]] [[Category:Scientific comparisons|Measurement systems]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox artist | name = Cornelis Apostool | image = Cornelis Apostool (1762-1844), by Charles Howard Hodges.jpg | image_size = 250px | alt = Portrait painting of Cornelis Apostool holding a book | caption = Portrait of Cornelis Apostool (ca. 1816) by [[Charles Howard Hodges]]<ref>{{nl icon}} [https://www.rijksmuseum.nl/nl/collectie/SK-A-654 Portret van Cornelis Apostool, eerste directeur van het Rijksmuseum, Charles Howard Hodges, ca. 1816], Rijksmuseum. Retrieved on 2013-04-25.</ref> | birth_name = Cornelis Apostool | birth_date = {{Birth date|1762|8|6|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Amsterdam]], [[Dutch Republic]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1844|2|10|1762|8|6|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Amsterdam]], [[Netherlands]] | nationality = Dutch ([[Dutch Republic|1]], [[Batavian Republic|2]], [[Kingdom of Holland|3]], [[United Kingdom of the Netherlands|4]], [[Netherlands|5]]), [[First French Empire|French]] | field = [[Painting]], [[drawing]], [[engraving]] | training = [[Hendrik de Meijer|Hendrik Meijer]] | movement = | works = | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = | elected = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> }}
'''Cornelis Apostool''' ({{IPA-nl|kɔrˈneːlɪs aːpɔsˈtoːl}}; 6 August 1762 – 10 February 1844) was a [[Dutch Republic|Dutch]] [[artist]], [[diplomat]], and [[museum director]].
==Biography== Cornelis Apostool was born on 6 August 1762 in [[Amsterdam]] in the [[Dutch Republic]]. His father was Jan Apostool, a [[Mennonite Church in the Netherlands|Mennonite]] and a [[merchant]] in [[animal skin]]s and [[cocoa bean]]s, and his mother was Cornelia de Witte. He was the eleventh of twelve children, six of whom died at a young age.<ref name="historici">{{nl icon}} Michiel Jonker, "[http://www.historici.nl/Onderzoek/Projecten/BWN_1780tot1830/lemmata/data/Apostool Apostool, Cornelis]", Historici.nl, 2012. Retrieved on 2013-04-25.</ref>
Apostool studied [[foreign language]]s with a French teacher in [[Delft]]. He then did an [[apprenticeship]] with a [[salesman]] in silver and gold in [[Rotterdam]]. From 1784 to 1786, he was a pupil of [[landscape painter]] [[Hendrik de Meijer|Hendrik Meijer]] at the [[Rijksakademie|art academy]] back in Amsterdam. In 1786, Meijer and Apostool went to England, where Apostool stayed and lived to work as an engraver of [[aquatint]]s.<ref name="historici"/>
He became the Commissary-general of Commerce in [[London]] around 1793. After the [[Batavian Revolution]], he negotiated the exchange of [[prisoner of war|prisoners of war]] for the [[Batavian Republic]] in London.<ref name="historici"/> In 1796, he returned to his native country.<ref name="bryan">{{Bryan (3rd edition)|inline=1|title=Apostool, Cornelis |volume=1}}</ref>
From 1798 to 1802, Apostool worked as an illustrator for the Agency of Interior Police and Water Management and later the Council of Interior Affaires.<ref name="historici"/>
In 1802, Apostool returned to his position as Commissary-general of Commerce in Londen, and he negotiated the release of Batavian ships. In 1806, he was appointed Government Secretary in the [[Dutch East Indies]]. But before he even arrived there, [[Louis Bonaparte]] became [[King of Holland]] and Apostool returned. In 1807, he briefly was a diplomat in the [[Kingdom of Naples]].<ref name="historici"/>
In 1808, Apostool was appointed director of the [[Rijksmuseum|Royal Museum]] in Amsterdam, which office he held until his death. He died on 10 February 1844 at the age of 81 in Amsterdam.<ref name="historici"/>
==Works== Some older biographies refer to Apostool as a [[Amateur|dilettante]],<ref name="bryan"/><ref>[http://www.historici.nl/retroboeken/nnbw/#source=1&page=88&size=800&accessor=accessor_index Apostool, Cornelis], Nieuw Nederlandsch Biografisch Woordenboek, 1911. Retrieved on 2013-04-25.</ref> but in a 2012 biography is claimed that he was more than a dilettante, because he made "artistically high quality [[aquatint]]s of [[painting]]s and [[drawing]]s of others".<ref name="historici"/>
He engraved a portrait of [[Lavinia Fenton]], afterwards Duchess of Bolton, after [[William Hogarth|Hogarth]], as well as landscapes for the ''Beauties of the Dutch School'', ''Select Views in the South of France'', ''Travels through the Maritime Alps'', and [[Thomas Daniell|Daniell]]'s ''Views of Hindostan''.<ref name="bryan"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|Cornelis Apostool}} * [https://www.rijksmuseum.nl/en/search?s=objecttype&f.principalMaker.sort=Cornelis+Apostool Works by Cornelis Apostool] in the collection of the [[Rijksmuseum]]
{{Authority control}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Apostool, Cornelis}} [[Category:1762 births]] [[Category:1844 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century Dutch painters]] [[Category:Dutch male painters]] [[Category:Artists from Amsterdam]] [[Category:Directors of museums in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Dutch engravers]] [[Category:Rijksmuseum Amsterdam]]

revision.comment: copy edit with [[Wikipedia:AutoWikiBrowser/General_fixes|General fixes]]; [[Template:Citation_Style_documentation#url|url trimming of identifying info]], replaced: as of January 2018 → {{as of|2018|January||lc=y}}
revision.text:
A '''credit rating''' is an evaluation of the [[credit risk]] of a prospective [[debtor]] (an individual, a [[business]], [[company]] or a government), predicting their ability to pay back the debt, and an implicit forecast of the likelihood of the debtor [[Default (finance)|defaulting]].{{cite book | last = Kronwald | first = Christian | title = Credit Rating and the Impact on Capital Structure | publisher = Druck und Bingdung | year = 2009 | location = Norderstedt, Germany | page = 3 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=CzjS5YV5nK8C&printsec=frontcover&resnum=2&ved=0CEoQ6AEwAQ&q=%22credit%20rating%22 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-3-640-57549-7}} The credit rating represents an evaluation of a [[credit rating agency]] of the qualitative and quantitative information for the prospective debtor, including information provided by the prospective debtor and other non-public information obtained by the credit rating agency's analysts. A credit reporting (or [[credit score]]) – in distinction to a credit rating – is a numeric evaluation of an individual's credit worthiness, which is done by a [[credit bureau]] or [[consumer credit reporting agency]]. ==Sovereign credit ratings== A [[Sovereign credit risk|sovereign credit rating]] is the credit rating of a [[Sovereignty|sovereign]] entity, such as a national government. The sovereign credit rating indicates the risk level of the investing environment of a country and is used by investors when looking to invest in particular jurisdictions, and also takes into account [[political risk]]. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:98%; float:right;" |+ '''Country risk rankings (Q4 2017)'''{{cite web|url=https://www.euromoney.com/research-and-awards/surveys-and-awards/country-risk-survey |title=Country risk survey - previous ranking from previous quarter, Euromoney Country risk |publisher=Euromoney.com}}[https://www.euromoney.com/research-and-awards/surveys-and-awards/country-risk-survey "Country Risk Full Results"]: Originally a bi-annual survey which monitors the political and economic stability of 185 sovereign countries, according to ratings agencies and market experts. The information is compiled from Risk analysts; poll of economic projections; on GNI; World Bank’s Global Development Finance data; Moody’s Investors Service, Standard & Poor’s and Fitch IBCA; OECD consensus groups (source: ECGD); the US Exim Bank and Atradius UK; heads of debt syndicate and loan syndications; Atradius, London Forfaiting, Mezra Forfaiting and WestLB. |+ Least risky countries, Score out of 100 |+ Source: Euromoney country risk ! Rank !! Rank Change !! Country !! Overall Score |- ! 1 | '''-''' | [[Singapore]] || style="text-align:right;"|88.6 |- ! 2 | '''-''' | [[Norway]] || style="text-align:right;"|87.66 |- ! 3 | '''-''' | [[Switzerland]] || style="text-align:right;"|87.64 |- ! 4 | '''-''' | [[Denmark]] || style="text-align:right;"|85.67 |- ! 5 | ▲2 | [[Sweden]] || style="text-align:right;"|85.59 |- ! 6 | ▼1 | [[Luxembourg]] || style="text-align:right;"|83.85 |- ! 7 | ▼1 | [[Netherlands]] || style="text-align:right;"|83.76 |- ! 8 | ▲4 | [[Finland]] || style="text-align:right;"|83.1 |- ! 9 | '''-''' | [[Canada]] || style="text-align:right;"|82.98 |- ! 10 | ▲1 | [[Australia]] || style="text-align:right;"|82.18 |} The "[[country risk]] rankings" table shows the ten least-risky countries for investment {{as of|2018|January|lc=y}}. Ratings are further broken down into components including political risk, economic risk. Euromoney's bi-annual country risk index monitors the political and economic stability of 185 sovereign countries.{{cite web|url=https://www.euromoney.com/research-and-awards/surveys-and-awards/country-risk-survey|title=Country risk survey |publisher=Euromoney.com}} Results focus foremost on economics, specifically [[sovereign default]] risk or payment default risk for exporters (also known as a [[trade credit]] risk). [[A. M. Best]] defines "country risk" as the risk that country-specific factors could adversely affect an insurer's ability to meet its financial obligations.{{cite web|url=http://www3.ambest.com/ratings/cr/crisk.aspx?l=1&Menu=Country+Risk |title=Country Risk |publisher=ambest.com |accessdate=2011-08-08}} ==Short- and long-term ratings== A rating expresses the likelihood that the rated party will go into [[Default (finance)|default]] within a given [[time horizon]]. In general, a time horizon of one year or under is considered short term, and anything above that is considered long term. In the past institutional investors preferred to consider long-term ratings. Nowadays, short-term ratings are commonly used.{{citation needed|date=June 2012}} ==Corporate credit ratings== {{Main|Bond credit rating}} Credit ratings can address a corporation's [[financial instrument]]s i.e. [[debt]] [[Security (finance)|security]] such as a [[Bond (finance)|bond]], but also the corporations itself. Ratings are assigned by [[credit rating agencies]], the largest of which are [[Standard & Poor's]], [[Moody's]] and [[Fitch Ratings]]. They use letter designations such as A, B, C. Higher grades are intended to represent a lower [[probability of default]]. Agencies do not attach a hard number of probability of default to each grade, preferring descriptive definitions such as: "the obligor's capacity to meet its financial commitment on the obligation is extremely strong," or "less vulnerable to non-payment than other speculative issues ..." (Standard and Poors' definition of an AAA-rated and a BB-rated bond respectively).{{cite book |title=The New Masters of Capital: American Bond Rating Agencies and the Politics of Creditworthiness |last=Sinclair |first=Timothy J. |authorlink=Timothy J. Sinclair |year=2005 |publisher=Cornell University Press |location=Ithaca, New York |isbn=978-0801474910 |page=36, Bond Rating Symbols and Definitions, Table 2, |url=http://www.cornellpress.cornell.edu/book/?GCOI=80140100511490 |accessdate=21 September 2013}} However, some studies have estimated the average risk and reward of bonds by rating. One study by Moody'scited by authors Herwig Langohr and Patricia Langohr claimed that over a "5-year time horizon" bonds it gave its highest rating (Aaa) to had a "cumulative default rate" of 0.18%, the next highest (Aa2) 0.28%, the next (Baa2) 2.11%, 8.82% for the next (Ba2), and 31.24% for the lowest it studied (B2). (See "Default rate" in "Estimated spreads and default rates by rating grade" table to right.) Over a longer period, it stated "the order is by and large, but not exactly, preserved".{{cite book|last=Langohr|first=Herwig|title=The Rating Agencies and Their Credit Ratings: What They Are, How They Work|year=2010|publisher=Wiley|page=48|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uChX5RuyDT4C&pg=PA48 |author2=Patricia Langohr}} {| class="wikitable" style="float:right" |- ! colspan="3" |Estimated spreads and
default rates by rating grade |- !Rating !Basis
Point
spread
{{cite news |title=The credit rating industry |last1=Cantor |first1=Richard |last2=Packer |first2=Frank |date=Summer–Fall 1994 |work=Federal Reserve Bank of New York Quarterly Review |publisher=Federal Reserve Bank of New York |url=http://www.newyorkfed.org/research/quarterly_review/1994v19/v19n2article1.pdf |issn=0147-6580 |page=10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429062213/http://www.newyorkfed.org/research/quarterly_review/1994v19/v19n2article1.pdf |archive-date=2011-04-29}}from Altman, Edward I "Measuring Corporate Bond Mortality and Performance" ''Journal of Finance'', (September 1989) p. 909–22Note: Based on equally weighted averages of monthly spreads per rating category. Spreads for BB and B represent data from 1979 to 1987 only, spreads for CCC, data for 1982–87 only. !Default
rateCantor, R., Hamilton, D.T., Kim, F., and Ou, S., 2007 Corporate default and recovery rates. 1920-2006, ''Special Comment:'' Moody's investor Service, June Report 102071, 1-48 page 24 |- |AAA/Aaa||43||0.18% |- |AA/Aa2||73||0.28% |- |A||99||n/a |- |BBB/Baa2||166||2.11% |- |BB/Ba2||299||8.82% |- |B/B2||404||31.24% |- |CCC||724||n/a |- !colspan="3" rowspan="3"|Sources: Basis spread from
''Federal Reserve Bank of
New York Quarterly Review'',
Summer-Fall 1994";
Default rate from study
by Moody's investment service |} Another study in ''Journal of Finance'' calculated the additional interest rate or "spread" corporate bonds pay over that of "riskless" US Treasury bonds, according to the bonds' rating. (See "Basis point spread" in table to right.) Looking at rated bonds for 1973–89, the authors found a AAA-rated bond paid 43 "[[basis points]]" (or 43/100 of a percentage point) over a US Treasury bond (so that it would yield 3.43% if the Treasury yielded 3.00%). A CCC-rated "junk" (or speculative) bond, on the other hand, paid over 7% (724 basis points) more than a Treasury bond on average over that period. Different rating agencies may use variations of an alphabetical combination of lowercase and uppercase letters, with either plus or minus signs or numbers added to further fine-tune the rating (see colored chart). The Standard & Poor's rating scale uses uppercase letters and pluses and minuses.{{cite book |author1 = de Servigny, Arnaud |author2 =Olivier Renault | title = The Standard & Poor's Guide to Measuring and Managing Credit Risk | year = 2004 |publisher = McGraw-Hill | isbn=978-0-07-141755-6}} The Moody's rating system uses numbers and lowercase letters as well as uppercase. While Moody's, S&P and Fitch Ratings control approximately 95% of the credit ratings business,{{cite web|last=Alessi|first=Christopher|title=The Credit Rating Controversy. Campaign 2012|url=http://www.cfr.org/united-states/credit-rating-controversy/p22328|publisher=Council on Foreign Relations|accessdate=29 May 2013}} they are not the only rating agencies. DBRS's long-term ratings scale is somewhat similar to Standard & Poor's and Fitch Ratings with the words high and low replacing the + and −. It goes as follows, from excellent to poor: AAA, AA (high), AA, AA (low), A (high), A, A (low), BBB (high), BBB, BBB (low), BB (high), BB, BB (low), B (high), B, B (low), CCC (high), CCC, CCC (low), CC (high), CC, CC (low), C (high), C, C (low) and D. The short-term ratings often map to long-term ratings though there is room for exceptions at the high or low side of each equivalent.{{cite web|title=DBRS: Short-Term and Long-Term Rating Relationships|url=http://dbrs.com/research/236758/short-term-and-long-term-rating-relationships.pdf|publisher=DBRS|accessdate=2013-06-28}} S&P, Moody's, Fitch and DBRS are the only four ratings agencies that are recognized by the [[European Central Bank]] (ECB) for determining collateral requirements for banks to borrow from the central bank. The ECB uses a first, best rule among the four agencies that have the designated ECAI status,{{cite web|title=External credit assessment institution source (ECAIs)|url=http://www.ecb.europa.eu/paym/coll/elisss/ecai/html/index.en.html|publisher=European Central Bank|accessdate=21 January 2014}} which means that it takes the highest rating among the four agencies – S&P, Moody's, Fitch and DBRS – to determine [[Haircut (finance)|haircuts]] and collateral requirements for borrowing. Ratings in Europe have been under close scrutiny, particularly the highest ratings given to countries like Spain, Ireland and Italy, because they affect how much banks can borrow against sovereign debt they hold.{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Marc|title=First crunch date in Europe's ratings calendar is April 11|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/12/19/ratings-spain-italy-idUSL6N0JY3OD20131219|accessdate=21 January 2014|newspaper=Reuters|date=19 December 2013}} A. M. Best rates from excellent to poor in the following manner: A++, A+, A, A−, B++, B+, B, B−, C++, C+, C, C−, D, E, F, and S. The CTRISKS rating system is as follows: CT3A, CT2A, CT1A, CT3B, CT2B, CT1B, CT3C, CT2C and CT1C. All these CTRISKS grades are mapped to one-year probability of default. {| style="text-align:center" |- ! colspan="2" style="background:White" |[[File:Moody’s logo.svg|center|frameless|208x208px]] ! colspan="2" style="background:White" |[[File:Standard & Poor's.svg|frameless]] ! colspan="2" style="background:White"|[[File:Fitch Ratings logo.svg|frameless]] ! colspan="2" rowspan="2" style="background:Sienna"| Rating description |- style="font-weight:bold" | style="background:DodgerBlue" |Long-term || style="background:SkyBlue" |Short-term || style="background:Crimson" |Long-term || style="background:LightCoral" |Short-term || style="background:Silver"|Long-term || style="background:Gainsboro"|Short-term |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |Aaa ||! rowspan="6" style="background:SkyBlue" | P-1 || style="background:Crimson"|AAA ||! rowspan="4" style="background:LightCoral"|A-1+ || style="background:Silver"|AAA || ! rowspan="4" style="background:Gainsboro"|F1+ || style="background:Tan"| Prime |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |Aa1 || style="background:Crimson"|AA+ || style="background:Silver"| AA+ || ! rowspan="3" style="background:Tan"|High grade |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |Aa2 || style="background:Crimson"|AA || style="background:Silver"|AA |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |Aa3 || style="background:Crimson"|AA− || style="background:Silver"|AA− |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |A1 || style="background:Crimson"|A+ || ! rowspan="2" style="background:LightCoral"|A-1 ||style="background:Silver"|A+ || ! rowspan="2" style="background:Gainsboro"|F1 || ! rowspan="3" style="background:Tan"|Upper medium grade |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |A2 || style="background:Crimson"|A || style="background:Silver"| A |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |A3 ||! rowspan="2" style="background:SkyBlue" | P-2|| style="background:Crimson"|A− || ! rowspan="3" style="background:LightCoral"|A-2 ||style="background:Silver"|A− || ! rowspan="2" style="background:Gainsboro"|F2 |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |Baa1|| style="background:Crimson"|BBB+|| style="background:Silver"|BBB+ || ! rowspan="3" style="background:Tan"|Lower medium grade |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |Baa2||! rowspan="2" style="background:SkyBlue" | P-3 || style="background:Crimson"|BBB||style="background:Silver"|BBB || ! rowspan="2" style="background:Gainsboro"|F3 |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |Baa3|| style="background:Crimson"|BBB−||style="background:LightCoral"|A-3 || style="background:Silver"|BBB− |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |Ba1 ||! rowspan="14" style="background:SkyBlue" | Not Prime ||style="background:Crimson"|BB+||! rowspan="6" style="background:LightCoral"|B||style="background:Silver"|BB+ || ! rowspan="6" style="background:Gainsboro"|B || ! rowspan="3" style="background:Tan"|Non-investment grade
speculative |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |Ba2 ||style="background:Crimson"|BB|| style="background:Silver"|BB |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |Ba3 ||style="background:Crimson"|BB−|| style="background:Silver"|BB− |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |B1 ||style="background:Crimson"|B+|| style="background:Silver"|B+ || ! rowspan="3" style="background:Tan"|Highly speculative |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |B2 ||style="background:Crimson"|B|| style="background:Silver"|B |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |B3 ||style="background:Crimson"|B−|| style="background:Silver"|B− |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |Caa1 ||style="background:Crimson"|CCC+|| ! rowspan="5" style="background:LightCoral"|C|| style="background:Silver"|CCC+|| ! rowspan="5" style="background:Gainsboro"|C|| ! rowspan="3" style="background:Tan"| Substantial risks |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |Caa2 ||style="background:Crimson"|CCC || style="background:Silver"|CCC |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |Caa3 ||style="background:Crimson"|CCC−|| style="background:Silver"|CCC− |- | rowspan="2" style="background:DodgerBlue" |Ca ||style="background:Crimson"|CC || style="background:Silver"|CC|| style="background:Tan"| Extremely speculative |- | style="background:Crimson"|C ||style="background:Silver"|C || style="background:Tan"| Default imminent |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |C ||style="background:Crimson"|RD|| ! rowspan="3" style="background:LightCoral"|D||style="background:Silver"|DDD|| ! rowspan="3" style="background:Gainsboro"|D|| ! rowspan="3" style="background:Tan"|In default |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |/ ||style="background:Crimson"|SD|| style="background:Silver"|DD |- | style="background:DodgerBlue" |/ ||style="background:Crimson"|D|| style="background:Silver"|D |} ==See also== * [[Government budget by country]] * [[List of countries by credit rating]] * [[List of countries by tax revenue as percentage of GDP]] * [[List of sovereign states by public debt]] '''Individuals:''' * [[Credit history]] * [[Credit score]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} == External links == * {{Commons category-inline|Credit rating}} [[Category:Credit]] [[Category:Rating]] [[Category:Credit rating| ]]

page.title: De Aragoniae Regibus et eorum rebus gestis libri V

revision.text:
'''''De Aragoniae Regibus et eorum rebus gestis libri V''''' (English: '''''The Kings of Aragon and their works, in 5 volumes''''') is a chronicle written in [[Zaragoza]] in 1509 by [[Lucio Marineo Siculo]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.enciclopedia-aragonesa.com/voz.asp?voz_id=8489|title=Gran Enciclopedia Aragonesa Online|last=SL|first=DiCom Medios|website=www.enciclopedia-aragonesa.com|access-date=2016-06-09}}</ref> documenting the feats of the kings of the Aragonese Renaissance. The chronicle was written in Latin and was later translated into [[Spanish language|Spanish]] by [[:es:Juan de Molina|Juan de Molina]]. The Spanish edition was published in [[Valencia]] in 1524 under the title ''Crónica d'Aragón'' (''Chronicle of Aragon'').
== References == <references />
[[Category:Iberian chronicles]]

[[File:Eclectic Chronicle.jpg|thumb|360px|[[L. W. King]]’s line-art for the Eclectic Chronicle.{{ cite book | title = Chronicles Concerning Early Babylonian Kings, Vol. II: Texts and Translations | author = L. W. King | publisher = Luzac and Co. | year = 1907 | pages = 147–155 }}]] The '''Eclectic Chronicle''', referred to in earlier literature as the ''New Babylonian Chronicle'', is an ancient [[Mesopotamia]]n account of the highlights of [[Babylonia]]n history during the post-[[Kassites|Kassite]] era prior to the 689 BC fall of the city of [[Babylon]]. It is an important source of historiography from the period of the early iron-age dark-age with few extant sources to support its telling of events. == The text == Although its provenance is unknown, it is thought to originate from Babylon itself as it is written in standard Babylonian in the late [[cuneiform]] script of the region. It was acquired by the [[British Museum]] in 1898 and given the accession number 98,0711.124, subsequently the Museum reference BM 27859. Approximately two-thirds of the text has survived with the top part of the tablet broken off, losing the beginning and end of the narrative. The work is written in a single column on a small tablet in the format of an administrative or economic text, suggesting it was for private use, in marked contrast to the official histories that were typically inscribed in two or more columns on a much larger object.{{ cite book | title = Assyrian and Babylonian Chronicles | author = A.K. Grayson | publisher = J. J. Augustin | year = 1975 | pages = 63–65 }} In many respects this chronicle shares the characteristics of [[Chronicle P]], as an episodic and laconic summary of the significant events of Babylonian history, but without the errors of that other work. It seems to have been a continuation, covering the post-[[Kassites|Kassite]] period beginning prior to the reign of [[Marduk-shapik-zeri|Marduk-šāpik-zēri]] (ca. 1082–1069 BC) through to sometime after that of [[Shalmaneser V|Salmānu-ašarid V]] (727–722 BC).{{ cite book | title = Reallexikon der Assyriologie und Vorderasiatischen Archäologie: Klagegesang – Libanon | chapter = Königslisten und Chroniken | author = A. K. Grayson | editor = D. O. Edzard | publisher = Walter De Gruyter | year = 1984 | page = 89 }} The narrative is divided into twenty two extant sections, each focusing on the events of the reign of a different Babylonian monarch (listed below) in chronological order with only a small number of omissions: # ”He carried off a great booty”, ''he'' presumably being [[Marduk-nadin-ahhe|Marduk-nādin-aḫḫē]] or [[Assyria]]n king [[Tiglath-Pileser I|Tukultī-apil-Ešarra I]], both of whom successfully raided one another’s territory # Marduk-šāpik-zēri - prosperous reign - this section is duplicated in the ''[[Walker Chronicle]]''{{ cite book | title = Assyriological Studies presented to F. R. Kraus on the occasion of his 70th birthday | chapter = Babylonian Chronicle 25: A Chronicle of the Kassite and Isin II Dynasties | author = [[C.B.F. Walker]] | editor = G. van Driel | publisher = Netherlands Institute for the Near East | date = May 1982 | pages = 398–406 }} # [[Adad-apla-iddina]] - Arameans and Suteans despoil the land - also duplicated in the ''Walker Chronicle''
(three reigns are skipped) # [[Simbar-shipak|Simbar-Šipak]] - makes throne of [[Enlil]] at Ekur-igigal
(two insignificant successors were ignored) # [[Eulmash-shakin-shumi|Eulmaš-šākin-šumi]] - event not preserved # 14th year of an unnamed king, probably [[Eulmash-shakin-shumi|Eulmaš-šākin-šumi]], when the ''[[Dynastic Chronicle]]'' relates he died and was succeeded by [[Ninurta-kudurri-usur I|Ninurta-kudurrῑ-uṣur I]] - event not preserved
(next king is omitted) # [[Mar-biti-apla-usur|Mār-bīti-apla-uṣur]] - event not preserved # [[Nabû-mukin-apli]] - event not preserved # ''n''th year, presumably of [[Ninurta-kudurri-usur II|Ninurta-kudurrῑ-uṣur II]], although this king only served eight months - event not preserved # [[Mar-biti-ahhe-iddina|Mār-bῑti-aḫḫē-idinna]] - event not preserved # [[Shamash-mudammiq|Šamaš-mudammiq]] - [[Adad-nirari II]] was king of Assyria # [[Nabu-shuma-ukin I|Nabû-šuma-ukin I]] - [[Tukulti-Ninurta II]] was king of Assyria # [[Nabu-apla-iddina|Nabû-apla-iddina]] - [[Ashurnasirpal II|Aššur-nāṣir-apli II]] was king of Assyria # [[Marduk-zakir-shumi I|Marduk-zâkir-šumi I]] - [[Shalmaneser III|Salmānu-ašarēdu III]] was king of Assyria # [[Marduk-balassu-iqbi|Marduk-balāssu-iqbi]] - event not preserved
(following king omitted) # ”For ''n'' years there was no king in the land.”
(next three kings are omitted) # [[Eriba-Marduk|Erība-Marduk]] - Aramaeans get their comeuppance # Erība-Marduk is honored with a second section - event not preserved
(following reign was skipped) # [[Nabonassar|Nabû-nāṣir]] - event not preserved # ? A section which could have been occupied by any of Nabû-nāṣir’s three successors - event not preserved # [[Tiglath-Pileser III|Tukultī-apil-Ešarra III]] - ascended the throne (of Babylon) # Salmānu-ašarid V - ascended the throne (of Babylon)
(lacuna) === Principal publications === * {{ cite book | title = Chronicles Concerning Early Babylonian Kings, Vol. II: Texts and Translations | author = L. W. King | publisher = Luzac & Co. | year = 1907 | pages = 57–69, 147–155 }} * {{ cite book | title = Assyrian and Babylonian Chronicles | author = A.K. Grayson | publisher = J. J. Augustin | year = 1975 | pages = 180–183 }} * {{ cite book | title = Mesopotamian Chronicles | author = [[Jean-Jacques Glassner]] | publisher = Society of Biblical Literature | year = 2004 | pages = 184–187 }} == External links == * The Eclectic Chronicle at [http://www.livius.org/cg-cm/chronicles/abc24/eclectic.html Livius] == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Eclectic Chronicle}} [[Category:Babylonia]] [[Category:Mesopotamian chronicles]] [[Category:Clay tablets]]
